_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP PROGRAM
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 
INLAND-JOSEPH FRUIT CO. (Wapato Plant)

A.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response

Inland-Joseph Fruit Company¿s accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  It is the policy of Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co.¿s emergency response policy involves the preparation of response plans and training of employees in evacuation and the handling of minor ammonia releases.

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co.¿s emergency response policy to major ammonia releases is to call the Yakima County ammonia response team.  This team is made up of area public safety responders and ammonia refrigeration personnel from area warehouses.  (Work in conjunction with local Fire Department and Police to ensure a proper and safe response.)

At Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. anhydrous ammonia is used on-site. Ammonia is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance (EHS) list.  

B.	Facility and Regulated Substance Handled

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. is a fruit processing and cold storage facility, located at 300 N. Frontage Road, Wapato, WA.  The facility is located in Yakima County, on the Yakima Tribal Nation.  The plant property is fenced and kept locked for the hours that it is not in operation.  

The regulated substance used at Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. is anhydrous ammonia (CAS# 7664-41-7). The use of anhydrous ammonia is as a refrigerant.

There are 12,300 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in two (2) single, independent refrigeration systems on the facility and is the only process subject to the RMP program.  The system with the greater amount of ammonia has 7,400 pounds in its inventory; the other has 4,900 pounds.

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. has established policies, procedures and training to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous substance release for the safety of its employees and

surrounding areas.

 

 
D.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co.¿s accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
·	Preventative maintenance program
·	Written safety procedures and safety equipment
·	Use of accurate and effective written operating procedures

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. also complies with: 
·	OSHA¿s and Washington State¿s process safety management rule.
·	Applicable Washington State¿s safety regulations (WAC¿s 296-24 and 296-62).
·	Applicable local fire codes.

The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to applicable codes and good practices at the time of installation.  Piping is elevated to prevent accidental damage to the system from moving vehicles.  Engine room doors are tight fitting and open outwards.  Other safety devices Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. utilizes include:
·	Computerized controls
·	High discharge pressure shut-down
·	Low suction pressure shut-down
·	Head water high discharge temperature shut-down
·	Oil pressure failure shut-down
·	Oil filter plugged shut-down on the screw compressor
·	Check valves
·	250 psi relief valves on the high pressure side, vented to atmosphere with 180 degree pipedown
·	150 psi relief valves on the low pressure side, vented to atmosphere with 180 degree pipedown
·	Personal protective equipment (PPE) ¿ Air-purifying respirator, gloves and goggles.  SCBA is also available.  
Operating Procedures have been prepared by Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. to be used by employees performing operational functions.  The operating procedures are kept in the Refrigeration office and in the Process safety Management book in the main office.  These procedures include: 
·	Pre-start up procedures
·	Routine operations
·	Maintenance
·	Response to minor releases
·	Emergency action plan

 
E.	Five-Year Accident History

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. has not had any accidents involving ammonia in the last five years.

F.	Emergency Response Program

In addition to the operating proce

dures, Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. has established Emergency Response Guidelines for releases involving ammonia.  These procedures are part of the ongoing training. 

Refrigeration personnel have received 24-hour Emergency responder training and the 8 hr. Emergency response team refresher in accordance with 1910.120.  The refrigeration specialists James Schibig and Mario Gallegos have been through the Ammonia Emergency response training conducted by PM Hazmat and Doubl-Kold.  
Dale Dougherty, HR and John Hunsaker, Facilities have also been through the same ammonia response training

We have two windsocks located at either end of the plant on top of the building and are visible from indoor refrigeration office and also visible outdoors upwind of any potential release.  Four company employees have taken required (24 hour) classes for Ammonia Response and are available to assist Fire department personnel.  (Certified Class A Hazmat Responders).  An eight hour refresher course is attended every year.  

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. is located in Yakima County, which has an ammonia response team.  

G.	Planned Safety Improvements

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. plans on installing ammonia leak detectors in the compressor rooms that will activate the alarm system and the emergency ventilation fans.

Procedures, such as lockout/tagout and PSM are reviewed and revised on a regular basis.  

Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. will continue to ensure that its employees assigned to work on the process receive current training.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN


FOR ANHYDROUS AMMONIA 

At 

INLAND-JOSEPH FRUIT CO.
WAPATO, WASHINGTON


06-20-2004


PREPARED FOR 

INLAND-JOSEPH FRUIT CO.


BY:

Dale Dougherty
Human Resource Manager 
Inland-Joseph Fruit Co. 
509-877-2126
